column4: I need  to know how to properly use make... I tried looking at "man make" but it didn't help... Can anyone help me? I tried ndiswrapper in the past (Now I don't need it) but right now I need to Make Apache 2.2.9
I need help using "make" in the terminal for Apache
apache 2.2.8 is in the repositories, which is a much better and safer option. do you REALLY need 2.2.9?
in Ubuntu, you generally should NOT "download" things. things are found in the repositories, and are compiled and optimized for Ubuntu, and receive regular security updates.
type "sudo apt-get install apache2" to get Apache 2.2.8 installed and running automatically.
as a side note, typing the first few letters of my tickname (which is TiredWolf, not TriedWolf) and then hitting TAB will get it auto-completed for you, which is handy.
the command is "sudo apt-get install apache2". you might want to stay on the channel, this time, for any further assistance
ahhh, I see.
Thanks, and I will stay on!

you can also install it using the "Synaptic" application in your menu (not Add/Remove Programs, though, as that will only offer a selection of graphical applications), if you're not a fan of the command line.

I don't mind the command line... I never thought of Synaptic... The only reson I actually downloaded it in the first place was because I couldn't find it in Add/Remove... Next time I have a program not graphical, I'll try it! But Apache already finished installing!

I don't mind the command line... I never thought of Synaptic... The only reson I actually downloaded it in the first place was because I couldn't find it in Add/Remove... Next time I have a program not graphical, I'll try it! But Apache already finished installing!
good, it should already be running then. point your browser to "http://localhost" and see.
Is Apache already running?
it should be
Where is it installed, and where are my htdocs?
uh?
i don't see anybody saying that. although it's usually assumed, since it's the current version
ubottu didn't say anything about your version, it's simply set for Hardy by default. besides, Hardy is 8.04, not 7.10
anyway, lsb_release -a will tell you both name and number
i suggest typing "apt-cache search mysql front". the answer is yes anyway
